subNodes.conversationText: root
As the young witch approached the house, <he/she> heard what sounded like revelry indoors. People were talking and laughing merrily. Music was being played.
<FirstName> hesitated. <He/She> didn't like the idea of walking in uninvited.
But maybe the hunter who killed Nnenne lived here, though, or was one of the party.
The young witch knocked on the door.
Even so, <he/she> slipped away.
The young witch knocked on the door.
"It's him! It's got to be him!" said someone inside.
[Continue.]
"Make yourself useful, Blauvelt. Open the door," said another.
[Continue.]
A pudgy man with an unprepossessing face and garish clothes opened the door. He cleared his throat and looked <FirstName> up and down.
[Continue.]
"It's not him."
[Continue.]
"Well? Who is it then?"
[Continue.]

Knott had become a normal gourd again. He rested at the young witch's feet.

"A wandering grocer," said the man named Blauvelt, seeing the gourd.
[Continue.]
"What! There are no wandering grocers around here!" cried a voice fom deeper in.
[Continue.]
Pharaoh, who had been observing from a nearby branch, alighted on the young witch's shoulder. Blauvelt's eyes went wide.
[Continue.]
"It's a witch! <He/She> has a crow and everything."
[Continue.]
"Oh? Better let <him/her> in. The last thing I need is another pox. My last case just cleared up."
[Continue.]
"What's another pox? You've slept with half the university."
[Continue.]
"Half the university! What are these foul rumors, love? I've slept with a good deal more than that."
[Continue.]
"Good deal for you, bad deal for them."
[Continue.]
"Nonsense! Blauvelt, bring the witch inside. The more the merrier! The less the -- more morose!"
[Continue.]
Before <FirstName> could make any objections, <he/she> was ushered into the midst of a party.
[Continue.]

Twenty to thirty people were crammed into the small house. Smoke hung in the air, as did the smell of sweat, wine, and ale. Everyone was laughing or talking or fighting.

There were students in the crowd, young and wearing academic robes and hoods. One had tied his robe above his midriff so that his belly button showed, and another was using her hood to catch a friend's vomit.

Another part of the company wore soiled cloaks, shabby armor, and the tools of banditry -- clubs, knives, and bows. One of these sat on a stool laughing uproariously as blood dripped from his head. Others whispered darkly to one another, no doubt discussing raids on caravans and how best to snooker fat merchants.
A party! It had been many days since <FirstName> had had this kind of fun.
<FirstName> felt ill at ease. <He/She> had never cherished parties or meeting new people. A witch, <he/she> reasoned, should be solitary.
<FirstName> looked on with detachment. Was Nnenne's murderer here?
<He/She> slipped away.
<FirstName> returned to the door. From the sound of it, the party hadn't ended.
The young witch knocked on the door.
<He/She> slipped away.
